title: Merritt Island shuts out Titusville
text:
Merritt Island shuts out Titusville Brian McCallum , FLORIDA TODAY 11:13 p.m. EDT October 15, 2015 Merritt Island's James Batch runs the ball during Thursday's game against Titusville. (Photo: Craig Bailey/FLORIDA TODAY) 3 CONNECT 10 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
TITUSVILLE Word on the street is that you don’t go to a Merritt Island football game to watch passing, but Jimmy Batch sure did put on a show on Thursday. Buy Photo Connor Allen of Merritt Island is chased down by Dante Mitchell of Titusville after he runs for big yardage in Thursday's game. Craig Bailey/FLORIDA TODAY Fullscreen Buy Photo Titusville's Jaleel Davis is pushed out of bounds by James Burt of Merritt Island during Thursday's game in Titusville. Craig Bailey/FLORIDA TODAY Fullscreen Buy Photo Merritt Island's Taquan Pratt (9) is brought down by Yusuf DeReese and Tommy Mack of Titusvlile during Thursday's game in Titusville. Craig Bailey/FLORIDA TODAY Titusvlile QB Chace Gadapee pitches the ball to a teammate during Thursday's game against Merritt Island. Craig Bailey/FLORIDA TODAY Merritt Island's James Batch runs the ball during Thursday's game against Titusville. Craig Bailey/FLORIDA TODAY Merritt Island's James Batch scores during Thursday's game against Titusville. Craig Bailey/FLORIDA TODAY Fullscreen Buy Photo Connor Allen of Merritt Island is chased down by Dante Mitchell of Titusville after he runs for big yardage in Thursday's game. Craig Bailey/FLORIDA TODAY Raleigh Barfield is congratulated after his TD by teammate Bailey Herring in Thursday's game. Craig Bailey/FLORIDA TODAY Merritt Island's Raleigh Barfield score a TD during Thursday's game in Titusville. Craig Bailey/FLORIDA TODAY Jaleel Davis of Titusville looks for running room during Thursday's game against Merritt Island. Craig Bailey/FLORIDA TODAY Titusville's Dontavious Marcus runs the ball during Thursday's game against Merritt Island. Craig Bailey/FLORIDA TODAY Titusville players gang tackle Merritt Island's Rydell Peterson during Thursday's game in Titusville. Craig Bailey/FLORIDA TODAY Merritt Island cheerleaders keep the crowd in the game. Craig Bailey/FLORIDA TODAY Fullscreen Buy Photo Dontavious Marcus of Titusville is taken down by Merritt Island's Peter Demorat (44) during Thursday's game in Titusville. Craig Bailey/FLORIDA TODAY Titusville High band members ride an imaginary roller coaster during Thursday's game. Craig Bailey/FLORIDA TODAY Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Last Slide Next Slide 
The junior quarterback didn’t miss, completing all 13 of his passes for 249 yards and three touchdowns in a 33-0 Mustangs win in District 14-5A play against Titusville. 
“Jimmy Batch is just a great quarterback,” said receiver Deben Peterson. “He’s all-around. He just gets you the ball.” 
Peterson was his first target, and the receiver did the most he could with it, taking the ball in right near the line of scrimmage, breaking through a cluster of defenders with help from a David Dufresne block and tip-toeing down the sideline for a 38-yard touchdown. 
“I caught it and kept my feet pumping,” he said. 
There was plenty of the traditional from the Mustangs, now 4-2 overall and 3-0 in district play a week before a date with Palm Bay. The offensive line opened up enough holes for Merritt Island to control the line of scrimmage, including one that allowed Raleigh Barfield score from the 25, right up the middle. 
Quenton Ashley did what Mustangs defensive backs often do, intercepting a Titusville pass in stride to end the one scoring threat the Terriers managed. He was part of a defense visibly tougher than in the district opener at Space Coast just a few weeks back when the Mustangs escaped with a 27-19 win. 
“We’re really communicating a lot better, one of the things we’ve been focusing on,” he said. Week 8: Friday's high school football capsules 
The Titusville defense had its moments and twice held the Mustangs out of the end zone. Dante Mitchell broke up a third-down pass in the first quarter to force a field goal attempt, and the middle of the Terriers defense stopped Merritt Island on a third-and-2 early in the second. 
That just allowed kicker Mason Denaburg to put on a show, first with a 33-yard field goal and then with a 40-yarder that looked as if it would have been good from considerably longer. He later missed a 54-yarder, but only because it bounced off the left upright – two-thirds of the way up – and back onto the field. 
When the Terriers left Connor Allen open in the middle of the field two minutes before halftime, it cost them. Batch found the tight end, and it turned into a 56-yard play that set up the quarterback’s own touchdown run, from 17 yards. 
But the Mustangs weren’t ready for intermission. Despite starting deep in his own territory, Batch engineered a touchdown drive that culminated eight seconds before halftime with a 16-yard scoring pass to Luke Clark. 
Contact McCallum at 321-242-3698 or bmccallum@floridatoday.com . Follow him on Twitter @Brian_McCallum and at facebook.com/FLtoday.brianmccallum.
